Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bishop> Anyone know why I seem to only get 5 to 6 connections when I have p2port 27485 open, maxconnections=40, server=1, listen=1,listenonion=1 in the config file?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Godballz> @bishop have you gotten more before from that? 5 is what I always get too but I never changed those values either

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <bishop> 5 is what you cap at unless you run a full node (like the explorers or pool servers run). Just stumped why I'm not maxing out on connections

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <miketout> @bishop it was dropped to 4 some months ago to reduce connectivity pressure across the whole network. at 4, open connections were often not picking up much traffic in the way of incoming. We raised it to 5 to strengthen the general connectivity and raise average connection count a bit, rather than jump to 6. Raising it to 5 did create more connectivity on some nodes that we were watching, but raising it to 6 might still strengthen things further if the network can easily handle it. Network connectivity overall seems pretty healthy, but if it can absorb a little more connectivity at 6 outgoing, because there's extra capacity on open nodes, then it won't hurt. thanks for the info.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <SmeLLyArMpiTs> Hi all.  Is it true that modern processors usually do more with less energy? Am considering the viability of using my old rigs. I revive an AMD triple core and despite plugging out hdd 2 and dvd rom , it burns 120watt at rest -.-

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <SmeLLyArMpiTs> I even took out the dedicated sound card

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Are you referring to modern cpus being more power efficient in general or verushash specifically as it uses modern instructions which renders older cpus less viable for mining?

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <SmeLLyArMpiTs> @zpajk i guess for wallet staking and mining ..     figured i use an old rig to be a 24/7   however the power seems too high ..  even my i5 intel 4 cores useless less than that amd

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <zpajk> Staking doesn't require much at all, but mining does. For mining the cpu should support AVX, AES-NI and PCLMUL, else the hashrate will suffer greatly. Older AMDs are power hungry in general.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <SmeLLyArMpiTs> yeah .. my another rig is a pentium R 2ghz    i think its pointless for that too

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <0x03> if power prices arent your limiting factor, theres some other altcoins you can mine with these.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <0x03> they're not useless, but it's not going to be the profitabilitybomb either

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> There are generally huge differences between old and new hardware in terms of compute per watt, yes

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> Power consumption has trended mostly flat (exception is memory), but obviously total theoretical compute has gone up dramatically

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> if we're comparing a chip from 2008 to 2018 for example, the newer chip is likely more than 10x as efficient when running flat-out

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> But for mining basically any currency, there are considerations besides pure compute output, like vector extensions, hardware crypto acceleration, etc

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> those are much more important than generational CPU improvement

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> If you're determined to do your own staking, I would suggest getting a used server off eBay. They are cheap, efficient and extremely reliable. Plus it's cool

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Vycid> However they are loud, so ensure you have a good spot for one

Author: Gateway#3763
